bibl.title: Letter from Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon to James E. Peabody, March 12, 1935

div1.p: Leon thanks Peabody for his work in securing pensions for yellow fever participants. She discusses her mother's death and conditions in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon to James E. Peabody, March 12, 1935
div1.opener:
Vedado, Havana, Cuba,
March 12, 1935.
Mr. James E. Peabody,
New York.
Dear Mr. Peabody:
div1.p:
In the process of settling down again in a new home after many
months of terrible experiences, I found a drawer full of letters,
which Mother was unable to answer before her death on November
29, 1933. Your kind letter of September 26th of that year was
among them. I can assure you that she reread it many times, and
that her last days were made happier by the knowledge that you
were to deliver lectures on mosquito-control in so many schools
and during the special memorial session for Major Reed at the
annual meeting of the A. P. H. Ass.

The deep-felt gratitude with which she followed your constant ef-
forts on behalf of her pension makes me feel ashamed not to have
written to you before this. Last April, upon receiving a note
from Gen. Kean, I answered it informing him of her passing away,
but until a short time ago I had not been able to find your ad-
dress.

During the last months of her two-year illness I was often tempt-
ed to write you. The nature of her disease -- cancer -- if known
over there might have helped in obtaining the pension, since it
would have been enjoyed only for so short a time. But I always
gave up the idea of telling our sad secret, for fear that the
publicity necessary in favoring your kind enterprise would reach
her in some way, adding the moral pain of anticipation to her in-
evitable physical sufferings. At the time of the first symptoms
(December, 1931) her disease was already too far advanced for
surgery; the only palliatives were X Ray and Radium treatments.
We were fortunate in deceiving her always about the seriousness
of her condition, and in avoiding the intensive pain of most
cases similar to hers, thanks to radium and opiates. It was be-
yond our power to relieve the discomforts of an ever-increasing
weakness and anemia.

You probably knew that I held a position in the Machado Govern-
ment. It was the only available job on our return from New Or-
leans. The salary was sufficient, together with the difference
in the rent of our larger home, to cover our living expenses.
Naturally Mother's treatments and nursing could not come out of
that; but the sale of family jewels and what “objects d'art” we
still possessed took care of those extraordinaries. My work in
the Presidential Household implied, of course, giving up my pro-
fessorship at the University, then very much entangled in the po-
litical intrigue which finally brought about Machado's downfall.
It was during the days that preceded the Revolution and later,
during the twenty-one-day-period of President Cespedes (when I
still held my position) that I frequently intended to make a
desperate appeal for her pension. It would have permitted us
2.
leave Cuba, thus avoiding the hardships of civil war, which in her
critical condition meant almost certain death. By the first of Oc-
tober I was already without a job. The terrible events that follow-
ed: the cannonade of the National Hotel five blocks from where we
lived; the killing in the streets; the utter impossibility for days
and days of obtaining medical supplies or adequate diet for a sick-
room. I am sure all this precipitated her end.

I was engaged at the time to a Major in the Cuban Army, who was
made a prisoner during the siege of the National Hotel, together
with 200 other fellow-officers. In March, 1934, he was set free
and we were quietly married. At first he was obliged to leave the
country; three months ago he returned and we are trying to remake
our home. He is also a lawyer, but in Cuba's present unsettled
state, there seems to be no opening for a man beginning a new ca-
reer at the age of thirty-eight. Though hard up, we are very hap-
py together. A man of culture, with an excellent library saved
from the wreck, we lead a quiet, retired, bookish life. With a
few private lessons I am giving to the children of old society
friends, I help to make ends meet and pay some of the debts still
pending since the last weeks of Mother's illness.

After all the strain of the past three years the mere lack of money
is hardly an inconvenience. We are both young and strong; it was
different when Mother, in her grievous illness, depended on me for
her every need and care. Sometimes, feeling I would be unable to
provide what was necessary, I desperately longed for her U. S. pen-
sion. Shortly after her death, it was granted. In Cuba also, the
civil pensions are now being paid quite regularly; they were twen-
ty months behind during all that time. Both arrived too late. I
feel certain satisfaction in remembering that she suffered no ac-
tual want, though of course deprived of many dainties and comforts,
I might have desired to offer her. I prefer not to think what
would have happened if she had lived many months more without an
allowance of some kind. There is no bitterness in my memories of
all those sorrowful circumstances. My grief at her loss has grad-
ually passed into that stage of fatalistic submission which the
living feel towards the unknown mystery of death; especially when
life becomes as difficult as it now is, on our unhappy Island. If
I bother you with the long tale of our woes, it is because I always
felt I owed your kind sympathy in our tribulations some kind of an
explanation.

But it is high time I brought this long letter to a close. Please
forgive my many grammatical mistakes; English does not come to me
as easily as it did to both my parents.

One more favor I would like to ask of you. Mother spoke to me
several times about a book on Biology which you were editing and
in which some reference was made to the work of the Yellow Fever
Commission. Am I imposing upon your kindness in requesting you to
allow me a copy of it?

Are you still desirous of getting in touch with Mr. Moran of this
city? If so, I would gladly try to find his present address for
you.

Please believe, Mr. Peabody, in the sincerity of my gratitude for
all your own, and the Biology Teachers Association's generous ef-
forts on behalf of my dear Mother. You can hardly imagine how
much your letters helped in keeping up her spirits during her two
years of illness. She never once lost hopes of obtaining her pen-
sion. Her American birth, childhood and maidenhood seemed to
sustain her faith in the justice of her claim to U. S. recognition.
It was not your fault that her trust was rewarded too late.
